clusters.title: US and Israel Launch Major Attacks on Iran Amid Calls for Regime Change
clusters.summary: The United States and Israel have initiated significant military operations against Iran, targeting major cities and military installations. President Donald Trump has urged the Iranian populace to rise against their government, framing the attacks as a step towards regime change. This escalation marks a critical moment in U.S.-Iran relations and raises concerns about regional stability.

items.title: Live updates: U.S. and Israel launch attack on Iran as Trump calls for regime change
items.description: The U.S. launched “major combat operations in Iran,” President Donald Trump said, promising to destroy its missiles and give rise to a change in government.

items.title: What to Know About the U.S. Attacks on Iran
items.description: The United States, joined by Israel, launched an attack on major cities in Iran, as President Trump called on Iranians to overthrow the government.

items.description: President Donald Trump encouraged the Iranian people to take over their government after announcing the United States and Israel are involved in “major combat operations” in Iran.

items.title: US and Israel launch joint attack on Iran as Trump urges regime change
items.description:
US president calls on Iranian people to ‘take over your government’, as explosions heard across central Tehran

  • US-Israeli attack on Iran – live updates

  • US and Israel strikes on Iran – what we know so far

Israel and the US have launched a war on Iran, with Donald Trump declaring the start of “major combat operations” and calling on Iranians to rise up against their government.

The US president’s comments came soon after explosions were heard across central Tehran. One apparent strike hit near the offices of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Iran is preparing a “crushing retaliation”, an Iranian official told Reuters.

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Trump Halts Use of Anthropic AI in Federal Agencies Amid Safety Concerns
clusters.summary: President Trump has ordered federal agencies to cease using artificial intelligence technology developed by Anthropic, a competitor of OpenAI. This decision follows a clash with the Pentagon regarding AI safety protocols and comes as OpenAI reaches an agreement with the Defense Department. The move highlights ongoing tensions in the rapidly evolving AI landscape and raises questions about the safety and regulation of AI technologies.

clusters.title: Paramount Acquires Warner Bros. Discovery as Netflix Exits Race
clusters.summary: Paramount has secured a $110 billion deal to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery, prompting Netflix to withdraw from the bidding process. Analysts suggest that Netflix's decision to step back may ultimately benefit the company, as it avoids a costly commitment. This development marks a significant shift in the competitive landscape of media acquisitions.

clusters.title: Bill Clinton Denies Wrongdoing in Epstein Inquiry Testimony
clusters.summary: Former President Bill Clinton testified before the House Oversight Committee, asserting that he 'saw nothing' and 'did nothing wrong' in relation to Jeffrey Epstein. His statements come amid ongoing scrutiny of Epstein's connections with high-profile individuals. The testimony follows a similar deposition by former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, highlighting the continued investigation into Epstein's activities and associations.

clusters.title: Legendary Singer-Songwriter Neil Sedaka Passes Away at 86
clusters.summary: Neil Sedaka, the renowned singer-songwriter known for his numerous hits from the 1960s and 1970s, has died at the age of 86. His contributions to music spanned multiple generations, influencing countless artists and leaving a lasting legacy in the industry. Sedaka's work included classics that resonated with fans worldwide, marking him as a significant figure in American pop music history.

clusters.title: Anthropic to Challenge Pentagon's Supply Chain Risk Designation

The challenge highlights ongoing tensions between government regulations and the tech sector's operational autonomy.

clusters.title: Man Charged for Defacing Churchill Statue in London
clusters.summary: Caspar San Giorgio, a 38-year-old man, has been charged with criminal damage after allegedly spraying graffiti on the statue of Winston Churchill outside the Houses of Parliament. The graffiti included slogans that criticized Churchill, prompting public and legal responses. San Giorgio is scheduled to appear in court on Saturday.

items.title: Man charged with criminal damage after Churchill statue sprayed with graffiti
items.description:
Caspar San Giorgio to appear in court over defacing of London statue with slogans including ‘Zionist war criminal’

A 38-year-old man has been charged with criminal damage after Winston Churchill’s statue outside the Houses of Parliament was sprayed with graffiti labelling the former prime minister a “Zionist war criminal”.

The Metropolitan police arrested Caspar San Giorgio, of no fixed address, shortly after 4am on Friday. He was charged in the early hours of Saturday morning and is due to appear at Highbury Corner magistrates court shortly.

Continue reading...

items.title: Man charged after Churchill statue defaced
items.description: Caspar San Giorgio, 38, of no fixed address, is due to appear in court on Saturday.

clusters.title: Mangione Avoids Death Penalty in CEO Murder Case
clusters.summary: Luigi Mangione will not face the death penalty for the murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson, as federal prosecutors have decided not to appeal a judge's ruling that barred the death penalty. This decision follows the 2024 killing of Thompson, which has drawn significant attention due to the high-profile nature of the victim. The outcome highlights the complexities of prosecutorial discretion in capital cases.

clusters.title: Anthropic Blacklisted by Trump Administration Over Pentagon Dispute
clusters.summary: The Trump administration has blacklisted AI firm Anthropic after the company declined to comply with demands from the Pentagon regarding its artificial intelligence technology. This decision highlights ongoing tensions between the government and private tech firms over national security and defense collaboration. The situation raises questions about the future of partnerships between the military and AI developers.

items.title: Trump admin blacklists Anthropic as AI firm refuses Pentagon demands - CNBC
items.description: Trump admin blacklists Anthropic as AI firm refuses Pentagon demands  CNBC

items.description: Anthropic rejects Pentagon’s AI demands  Politico

clusters.title: Senators and Tech Employees Support Anthropic Against Pentagon
clusters.summary: A group of U.S. senators has called for a ceasefire in the ongoing conflict between the Pentagon and Anthropic, an AI safety and research company. In a show of solidarity, hundreds of employees from Google and OpenAI have also voiced their support for Anthropic, highlighting concerns over the implications of the Pentagon's actions on the AI industry. This situation raises significant questions about the relationship between government and technology firms in the evolving landscape of artificial intelligence.

items.title: Senators urge ceasefire in Pentagon’s fight with Anthropic - Politico
items.description: Senators urge ceasefire in Pentagon’s fight with Anthropic  Politico

clusters.title: Trump Discusses Potential Military Action Against Iran
clusters.summary: Former President Donald Trump expressed a willingness to use military force against Iran, stating that while he would prefer not to engage in conflict, there are circumstances that may necessitate such action. His comments reflect ongoing tensions between the U.S. and Iran, highlighting the complexities of foreign policy decisions in the region.

clusters.title: Anthropic Rejects Pentagon Demands for AI Development
clusters.summary: Anthropic's CEO announced that the company will not comply with the Pentagon's requests regarding the use of artificial intelligence, citing ethical concerns. This decision has garnered support from some lawmakers who view it as a principled stand against military influence in AI development. The situation highlights ongoing debates about the role of technology companies in national security matters.

clusters.title: Mass Graves Discovered in Eastern Congo Following Rebel Exit
clusters.summary: Authorities in eastern Congo have reported the discovery of mass graves containing 171 bodies, following the withdrawal of rebel forces from the area. The find raises serious concerns about potential human rights violations and the ongoing violence in the region. Local officials are investigating the circumstances surrounding the deaths as the situation continues to unfold.

clusters.title: State Farm Declares $5 Billion Dividend and $100 Refunds for Customers
clusters.summary: State Farm has announced a $5 billion dividend and plans to issue average refunds of $100 to its car insurance customers. This decision comes as the company aims to return excess funds to policyholders amidst a profitable financial period. The move is expected to benefit millions of customers, highlighting the company's commitment to its policyholders.

clusters.title: US Embassy in Jerusalem Authorizes Staff Departure Amid Iran Tensions
clusters.summary: The U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem has authorized the departure of nonemergency personnel due to escalating tensions and the potential for an Iranian strike. Senator Marco Rubio is set to visit Israel during this period, highlighting the ongoing concerns regarding regional security. This decision underscores the heightened alertness of U.S. officials in response to threats in the area.

clusters.title: FedEx to Refund Customers Any Tariff Refunds Received
clusters.summary: FedEx has announced that it will return to customers any refunds it receives from the U.S. government related to tariffs imposed during the Trump administration. This decision comes as the company seeks to address concerns over the financial impact of these tariffs on its clients. The move is seen as a way to maintain customer trust and support amid ongoing discussions about trade policies.

clusters.title: Olympic Hockey Star Disavows AI-Generated White House Video
clusters.summary: A U.S. Olympic hockey star has publicly rejected an AI-generated video shared by the White House, stating that the content does not reflect their views. The athlete emphasized that they would 'never say' the statements attributed to them in the video, which has been labeled as 'clearly fake.' This incident raises concerns about the use of artificial intelligence in political messaging and its potential to mislead the public.

clusters.title: Anthropic Reports Stalled AI Negotiations with Pentagon Ahead of Deadline
clusters.summary: Anthropic has reported that discussions with the Pentagon regarding artificial intelligence policy have made 'virtually no progress' as a critical deadline approaches. The company faces a challenging situation, with potential implications for its future collaboration with the defense sector. This standoff highlights the complexities of integrating AI technologies within military frameworks and the urgency for policy advancements.

clusters.title: Novartis Settles with Henrietta Lacks' Estate Over Cell Use
clusters.summary: Novartis has reached a settlement with the estate of Henrietta Lacks regarding the use of her cells, which were taken without consent in the 1950s and later contributed to significant medical advancements. This case highlights ongoing ethical concerns surrounding medical research and consent, particularly in relation to marginalized communities. The settlement aims to address the legacy of Lacks and the impact of her cells on modern medicine.

items.title: Novartis settles with woman's estate over use of her "stolen" cells to advance medicine - CBS News
items.description: Novartis settles with woman's estate over use of her "stolen" cells to advance medicine  CBS News

items.description: Novartis settles with Henrietta Lacks' estate over use of her 'stolen' cells to advance medicine  AP News

clusters.title: Supreme Court Ruling Challenges Trump's Tariff Authority
clusters.summary: A recent Supreme Court ruling has raised questions about the Trump administration's authority to impose tariffs, prompting the White House to engage in damage control regarding its trade deals. While President Trump maintains that existing trade agreements remain secure, international partners express uncertainty about the implications of the ruling. This development could significantly impact U.S. trade relations and economic policy moving forward.

clusters.title: DOJ Files Lawsuits for Voter Roll Access in Five States
clusters.summary: The Department of Justice has initiated lawsuits against five additional states to obtain access to their voter registration rolls. This action is part of a broader effort to ensure compliance with federal voting laws and to enhance election integrity. The lawsuits reflect ongoing tensions between state and federal authorities regarding voter data management.

clusters.title: Minnesota Judge Warns ICE and Prosecutor of Contempt Charges
clusters.summary: The chief federal judge in Minnesota has issued a warning to both the state's top prosecutor and Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials, demanding compliance with court orders. Failure to adhere to these directives could result in criminal contempt charges. This situation highlights ongoing tensions between judicial authority and immigration enforcement practices.

clusters.title: Columbia Student Elmina Aghayeva Released from ICE Custody
clusters.summary: Elmina Aghayeva, a Columbia University student, was released from ICE custody following a meeting between President Trump and New York City Mayor Eric Adams. Aghayeva's detention had raised concerns about immigration enforcement and its impact on students. Her release highlights ongoing discussions about immigration policy and the treatment of international students in the U.S.

clusters.title: Texas Bible Curriculum to Receive Hundreds of Corrections
clusters.summary: Texas' recently approved Bible-infused curriculum for public schools will undergo significant revisions, with hundreds of errors identified by educators and officials. The corrections come after the material faced scrutiny and pushback upon its introduction in classrooms. This development highlights ongoing debates over educational content and its implications for public education in the state.

clusters.title: Kansas Invalidates IDs and Birth Certificates for Transgender Residents
clusters.summary: The state of Kansas has invalidated over 1,000 driver's licenses and birth certificates belonging to transgender residents. This decision impacts individuals' ability to use these documents for identification purposes, raising concerns about the rights and recognition of transgender individuals in the state. The move has sparked a debate over the implications for personal identity and legal documentation.

clusters.title: Maduro Seeks Dismissal of Indictment in U.S. Court
clusters.summary: Nicolas Maduro, the deposed president of Venezuela, has requested a U.S. judge to dismiss the indictment against him. His legal team argues that U.S. actions have infringed upon his rights by obstructing access to funds necessary for his defense. This legal maneuver highlights ongoing tensions surrounding Maduro's status and the implications of international law.

clusters.title: Cuba Reports Four Killed in Speedboat Shooting Incident
clusters.summary: Cuban authorities have confirmed that four individuals were killed in a shooting incident involving a speedboat, which they allege was attempting to infiltrate the country. The incident highlights ongoing concerns regarding illegal immigration and security along Cuba's maritime borders. Officials are investigating the circumstances surrounding the shooting and the identities of those involved.

clusters.summary: A prominent Supreme Court litigator has been convicted of tax fraud related to income earned from high-stakes poker games. clusters.title: Texas Grand Jury Declines Indictments in Shooting of US Citizen
clusters.summary: A Texas grand jury has decided not to indict federal immigration agents involved in the fatal shooting of a U.S. citizen. The decision highlights ongoing tensions surrounding immigration policy and law enforcement practices.

clusters.summary: Bill Gates discussed his connections to Jeffrey Epstein during a recent Gates Foundation meeting, emphasizing transparency regarding the matter.
